reviewText:
Update after completing the game. Although this list is a lot of negatives, I think the game was definitely worth its asking price. It really needed some ironing out, but the execution is otherwise amazing.

+ Voiceacting is good. Cartoony as hell, but good.
+ Art style is cool. Also cartoony.
+ Animations are fairly smooth.
+ The setting and story are both unique and GREAT, and I wouldn't hesitate to describe the whole game as cute."
+ The puzzle solving mechanics are very interesting. There's a lot of unique abilties you have
date: and they each have a different cost. There are usually several different ways to approach every situation
recommended: and you have to think ahead to avoid wasting certain resources.\n+ Failure doesn't usually mean a lot of restarting - it usually means you'll have to try again a different way
hoursPlayed: since you've wasted resources.\n+ The difficulty ramp has a good
voteText: satisfying feel to it.\n+ I love and look forward to the dialogue. It can be cheesy
helpfulPercent: but it knows that.\n+ The characters aren't incredibly remarkable
votesHelpful: but they certainly aren't boring templates.\n\n- VERY buggy. Enemies can get stuck in unreachable places
votesTotal: entire areas can become uncompleteable(although you can reset an area if that does happen)
commentsCount: sometimes not(something that I speculate has to do with getting stuck between non-square hitboxes)

column17: and yet other enemies' movement is too wonky for a perfect clear to be worthwhile.\n- Damage is not always properly communicated. If you're not paying attention

column19: green goo makes it look like it didn't damage you because nothing really happens - but it did.\n- The procedural generation of the main areas is unfortuantely not quite as interesting as it sounds
column20: because you get so many resources that there is little to no challenge in any of the puzzle portions - it's all platforming
column21:
navigating and not being chewed up by electrons.
- SFX are just a tad annoying.
- Camera movement is awful in some zones.

column22: but you gain momentum in a very unstable manner.\n- It feels like there's a lot of unused potential in the way antiquarks act.\n- Short play length - about nine hours if you're not unrealistically going for a perfect clear. Fifteen to twenty hours in that case."

reviewText:
This is one of my first reviews and it may be positively up quarkian in nature.  I caught a fleeting glimpse of the title of this game and I knew that it must be mine; it was one of the best decisions I have ever made.  The humor and style of the game feels like a nostalgic take on platformers from the 80's - 90's, such as Earthworm Jim / Gex / Star Fox, while the modern upkeep on the gameplay and art style is sophisticated and smooth.  As big a draw as the wise cracking protagonist, the spiffy art, or the silky gameplay may be the best part of this game by far is the SCIENCE NERD HUMOR OMG!

If you are a nerd, a geek, a science dork, if you ever knocked someone out with a science textbook before.... this is the game for you!  It's challenging, engaging, and dear fluffy Cthulhu funny.

reviewText: It's a downright shame this doesn't have more publicity then it does, because this game is downright fantastic. Wonderful design decisions all around, from the very clever use of the open world puzzle platforming combined with a resource management mechanic (if you want to look at it like that) to make the player think on their feet when facing their challenges. Combine that with a nerdy sense of humor combined with well done voice acting, and you have a game that you should pick up.\n\nI have more thoughts on the game here: http://youtu.be/Es-Kfibrc8A

reviewText:
I think it's fun (2 hours of gameplay so far). It's not a great game but certainly something that's enjoyable. The puzzles are nice and the characters are weirdly good. The game is rather forgiving when you make a mistake. You can die in this game, but then again, you are Schrödinger's cat! You are neither dead nor alive so you can keep on dying as many times as you want.


And I like some of the jokes (baby" was really good). You don't have to be a quantuum scientist to understand that leptons are "kleptons" in this game ;)"

reviewText: Great puzzle platformer with a silly sense of humour.  This game does not hold your hand - in a great way.  The puzzles are at times fiendishly difficult, but all solvable within the design of the game, often in a variety of different ways.  The humour and voice acting are pretty fantastic as well, thanks to awesome voice work by the guy who played Marty McFLy in the Back to the Future video games.  Very fun game, especially if you're up for a challenge.

reviewText:
This is a really great game - especially if you love physics!

The jokes are definitely funny if you understand them.

The game mechanics (up, down, top, bottom quarks) are really interesting - it's not something that's done often. This actually makes you think on how to solve the puzzle.
I have played this at Insomnia 52, and now I can finally play it home.
I'd definitely recommend it!

reviewText: Awesome fusion of a LucasArts game and a science-based Mario Bros. Manipulating quarks gives the game a unique, puzzle solving angle that elevates it above the usual family-friendly platformer (controls are a bit imprecise, though). Especially love how the approach to science in the game is not only lighthearted, but shows that loving science does not mean being anti-religion or against faith.\n\nLove it so far and can't wait to dive in more!

reviewText:
Zany feline physic-al fun!

Already adore the eccentric characters, Nickelodean-style animation and appalling science puns...the voice-over work is hilarious (Marty McFly?), while I can see that the range of combo-puzzles are going to keep me challenged for hours.

Reminds me of classic platformers from the 90s, and I can tell that this game has been really lovingly nutured by the developer.  A great, visually distinctive game that is bang on the funny bone!

reviewText:
I've played a good bit of the game until now, so I think a review at this point seems right.

I would definetely recommend this game, I love the humour it offers - and the voice acting is done astonishingly good for a small (and not very known) game like this. The plot is funny as well.

The gameplay suits me quite nicely - although it might not be the most challenging one in a platformer, especially not for the veterans of that genre out there.
It has some cool new sides to it - you play on the keyboard only, but with both hands - one for moving, one for the quarks. By combining the quarks with your arrow keys, you proceed through the game - forming platforms, shields and so on...

Although this game has its flaws (some minor bugs with terrain you want to explode and which doesn't work properly, and sometimes the controls can be a bit slow), I fully recommend it. The price is quite cheap, so the ratio between what you pay and what you get is pretty good!

reviewText: The graphics are a little clunky, but the platforming is solid. And for a cartoony character platformer, this game is well-written and surprisingly particle physics-savvy.

date:
this will be good." Team 17 also was involved with games from the Worms series (which I love). They did not disappoint:

It's a great platformer with an interesting "combo" system that uses quarks you find along the way. It has a simple start tutorial. I haven't beaten the game yet but I am having a lot of fun solving the puzzles it is presenting me. I have noticed it has a "restart area" option (pressing ENTER) and I did not notice a life counter (so I assume infinite lives). So there's really not a reason to stop playing if you can't beat a puzzle.

It's probably one of the best purchases I have ever done in this account
recommended: nice change from games like CS:GO."

reviewText:
I would recommend this game as a cautious recommendation at best. The combo mechanic with okay-if-floaty platforming controls makes for a fun, original experience.

The real question you should ask before purchasing is how much can you stand ear-grating one-liners or annoying personalities? Also, do you like physics?

Schrodinger's Cat: The Procrastinator of Videogame Character Abilities
Like most cats, they don't do the work but get other people to do the work for them. This is how Schrodinger works with the combo ability system.

Here you combine three quarks (out of four) in order to result in some combination. There are fourteen total and nearly all of them are well-used throughout the game.

You can make a parachute, a bubble-shield, a missile, a decoy disco machine and even a helicopter. The four quarks are given to you from the start, and they serve as Schrodinger's abilities (besides his attack) and as his groupies.

On a controller, the shoulder buttons and triggers use one type of quark. On keyboard they have their respected keys.

Although cumbersome at first, you'll be able to make these combinations fast like in a fighting game. You'll learn the most useful combos not too long in the HUB world, and the puzzles allow for some failure. If you ever forget them, you have all combos listed in the pause menu.

In-between the smaller, focused areas, the game has this HUB-world" (which I use in quotations as there's nothing to do other than collect particles). Besides the optional fetch-quest
date: the area serves as a means for the player to learn on his/her own pace with the superflous amounts of quarks.\n\nAll of these gameplay ideas sound wonderful on paper
recommended: and the tutorial isn't unclear for people not familiar with quantum mechanics nor too long for seasoned platformers. Unfortunately
hoursPlayed:
the HUB areas are my main gripe with this game.

Mechanics Are Best When Quantized
Ironic enough
voteText: a game about quantum mechanics is the most fun when you set enough limitations on all the probabilities you can have. Only then do you see the game's potential.\n\nThe procedurely generated layouts are a nice touch for replay value
helpfulPercent: but the HUB environments aren't interesting to explore as the only objective is to collect X amount of each particle.\n\nThankfully
votesHelpful:
you do not have to collect everything. The only time you need to collect everything in the area is when the game has some arbitrary reason to get progress. The only other thing you need to keep an eye out for are the Charm Particles to finish the game.

When you are in those "dungeon" areas with a limited amount of quarks (which is limited by the checkpoints) is where I think the game works best.

The abundance of quarks offers no challenge to get around the generated HUB. At worst
votesTotal: it means you may have to backtrack if you cannot progress without one type of quark. At best
votesFunny: it makes for a tutorial at your own pace in disguise. This is almost a different game to when you're in the dungeon areas.\n\nWhen limited
commentsCount: you have to think how to make the best with what you got. You learn about some combos' synergy and how to better reserve each type of quark. The checkpoints enforced a difficulty scale rather than some arbirtrary impasse
column16: and because I had so many spare quarks that means there are multiple solutions too.\n\nIf the game was only of these dungeon areas and running-sections
column17: then I think you'd have a well-loved classic. It would be a shorter game

but it more polished experience... Until the end boss.

Nothing about that fight had anything to do with Schrodinger's Cat's mechanics. Why couldn't the game ended with something that fits the game's focus and its mechanics?

Aside from a weak

the biggest problem about Schrodginer's cat is its dumb smart humor.

reviewText:
Its fun, the science jokes and voice acting are both awesome, and the game runs smoothly and beautifuly. If only the game wasn't so buggy that it was unplayble. Quarks that were nessasary to complete the level would not spawn, enemies could jump out of the world to avoid me, and at high speeds I could clip through walls. A few patches are needed badly, but if the bugs are fixed this game would be worth the money!

EDIT: no.
As I breezed my way through the game, I realized that this game is not worth it. Having just finished the game, most of it was moderatly easy (with execption to the runner levels). However, the final boss and the ending cutscence were terrible. More glitches, more going through walls and overall more cheap deaths from the running sections really soured this game for me. Also the final boss was defeated using none of the mechanics I learned in-game, which is not how any game should end. I should also add that the recent patch didn't even fix a single bug (that I noticed).
While the game has some redeming factors and a high framerate throughout (even when I cranked up the options) it was utterly a waste of my time.

reviewText:
Overall: 7.5/10

I'm a Physics grad so I was bound to get this game the moment I saw its name! It was a pleasant surprise that the humour in the game too was wacky, corny and physics-y throughout. The writing is good, the mechanics and the concept are very well thought out. If you have played DotA, this is like playing invoker - instead of three orbs, you have to conjure combos of three quarks, and then use them to solve a puzzle platformer.

There isn't much of story" to go with this game. You're the cat
date: and you must navigate your path through the Particle Zoo to reach the control center
recommended: AKA Nucleus. There are three baddies: Gluons
hoursPlayed: Leptons and Bosons. Beating each of them is different and you must go through their respective habitats
voteText: which are quite well designed and vary from easy to moderate difficulty. The levels in between are generated randomly
votesHelpful: whatever that means. Except for achievement hunting
votesTotal: there is nothing like "easter eggs" in this game
votesFunny: and it's pretty much linear. I would recommend to limit playing this game about 30-45 mins
commentsCount: or 2 to 3 chambers at a time (whichever is smaller). That way you won't feel the game or the jokes to be repetitive
column16: and you'll go through it over ~10 days (my gametime includes the one night I forgot the game in minimize and slept off). Catching baddies and solving puzzles is satisfying in moderate doses
column17:
and the 3-4 "boss fights" are also a good change of pace.

Impressive parts:
-All the voice acting is done by one guy. Whoa!
-Achievement hunting is fun but non essential
column18: exactly as it should be.\n-The 3 Baddie habitats are tightly designed.\n-Next to no bugs (in fact only one well-known bug: infinite loading at the start
column19: which is easy to resolve).\n-Soundtrack is just enough repetitive to be in the background and just enough dynamic to not be annoying or boring.\n-Press TAB to zoom out and check out the area around. What an amazing way to incentivise pre-planning over hit-and-trial attitude! Really impressed me

more platformers should have this.

Not-so-cool parts:

-The cat when moving in spaces 1 unit in height

reviewText:
PROs:
+ funny dialog and story
+ great and funny voices
+ fun platformer
+ not too difficult but difficult enough to be satisfaying
+ ps3 controller worked flawesly (support had been added just a few days before i played it)

Neutral:
-+ having to remember the combos seems is going to be overwhelming the first time... but is not too bad in the end... there arent that many combos to learn, all makes sense, and you dont need to press them in any particular order. (I first thought you had to press them in the order shown!)
-+ the game reseted and lost my save during the final boss fight after hitting it twice (i think you beat him after hitting it 3 times), and I didnt want to redo the game, so technically, i havent beat the game yet, but looking at the forums, the developer seems very responsive :)

CONs:
- charms quarks are needed to progress in the game but you arent told so. If you dont collect them, you have to redo the zones to get them without a hint of what zones have charms left or where they are. Its easier the second time because walls where you punched a hole keep the hole and you can use the quarks in other ways, but you have to complete the WHOLE zone again, including already beaten bosses.
- boss fights. You have to make combos while running... with a time constrain... without save points. It wasnt so bad, i was able to beat them in about 20 minutes of trial and error, but im not sure it was a fun battle
- In the final boss you run aimlessly for too long

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played for humor, the gameplay can get repetative at first, but once you get a bit farther it changes up a bit. Still one of my favorite games. A lot of chemistry/physics jokes.

reviewText: Pure awesome. Corny physics jokes in a well designed platform game, in which quarks make cute noises.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have no idea why as I write this the game only has a meta rating of 59.  Its has just hilarious physics based comedy and if you have even a passing understanding of quantum physics you will be laughing your socks off, even if you dont though its still got a really quirky funny sense of humour anybody could enjoy.

The gameplay itself is simple enough but deceptively so as the platform levels require you to really think at times.  The game is essentially a platformer game with puzzle solving elements and a funny story told in cut sequences.

Definately worth buying and enjoying, even more so if factorals dont scare you :)

reviewText:
With its quirky style and retro leanings, I had high hopes for this one... which only makes a negative review more difficult to write.

There's some really fun move design here, which comes into play in the puzzle-platforming segments, and wide-open worlds to explore. The main problem, therefore, is not one of substance, but of style.

It's alright to be clever"

reviewText: This is not an evaluation of the game itself, but a warning: the game won't run under certain OS locale setting (including, but not limited to, Japanese.)\n\nThe cause was identified, and the dev kindly promised an upcoming patch.  I will re-evaluate the game when it materializes, but until then, in all good conscience I can't recommend what's broken.

reviewText: Irconically this game has pretty bad gameplay physics and very unstable physics overall.\nThe worst is that you may ghost through wall very often when your frame rate is low (happened to me three times in 10 minutes). The game is just buggy as hell and when you get stuck and want to reset your player, you either are lucky and fall out of the level and die, or you cannot move out of the wall anymore and have to start over the whole level.

reviewText:
First impression: Definitely enjoyable. But it's a good thing they give you checkpoints because you WILL be getting stuck/dying because of glitches. Example: running through solid walls and falling through solid floors.

After advancing past the initial introductory area of the game: Man, why do I keep getting stuck inside of walls and under the floor? It shouldn't happen this often.

The last straw: Started a new stage. Hmm, this has some nice and interesting strategy to it. Lemme just go down here and... oh well whaddaya know I fell straight through the floor, totally bypassing the save checkpoint. Also, I seem to be stuck here. Need to restart level. Restarted level, same falling-through-floor glitch happened again in the same spot. Restarted level again, glitch again. GIVE UP!!!
